3.
 Upgrading the embedded version of IBM Cloud
Private 
If you installed the stand-alone version of Cloud Pak for Data version 2.1.0.1 or
earlier, you must upgrade the embedded version of IBM® Cloud Private to version
3.2.0 before you can upgrade your Cloud Pak for Data installation to version 2.1.0.2.
This step is not necessary when upgrading from Cloud Pak for Data version 1.2.1 to
version 2.1.0.1 or earlier. 
 Before you begin 
 
Ensure that you completed Obtaining the installation files for upgrade.Do not
complete this task if you installed Cloud Pak for Data in your existing IBM Cloud
Private environment. For the steps that you must complete, see Upgrading Cloud
Pak for Data. 
 About this task 
 
The Cloud Pak for Data installation package includes the IBM Cloud Private
installer. If you completed Obtaining the installation files for upgrade, you should
have a copy of the IBM Cloud Private installer on the master node (master-1) of
your cluster. Also, ensure that the yum rpm sshpass is installed on master-1 (use
the command yum list installed | grep
sshpass to check). 
 Procedure 
 
SSH into the master node (master-1) of your cluster as root:ssh root@MASTER_1_IP 
 
Ensure that you are authenticated to the following command-line interfaces:
IBM Cloud Private command-line interface. Microsoft Azure example:cloudctl login
--skip-ssl-validation -a https://<azure cloud>:8443 -u <adminuser> -p <adminuserpassword> -n default -c
id-myicp-account 
Kubernetes command-line interface (kubectl). For example:kubectl get pods -n
kube-system 
Helm. For example:helm version --tls 
Or if TLS is not set up for Helm: 
helm version 
The command should return the version information for the Helm server and
Helm client. 
Docker registry. For example:docker login DOCKER_REGISTRY_URL -u USER_NAME -p 
 
Change to the /installation_directory/upgrade directory and run the following
command to start the upgrade:./installer.x86_64.nnn --platform-upgrade=ICP 
Tip: Alternatively, you can automatically upgrade the Cloud Pak for Data Docker
using the --platform-upgrade=docker flag, GlusterFS using the --
platform-upgrade=gluster flag, or all three (Cloud Pak for Data, docker,
and GlusterFS) using the --platform-upgrade=all flag. 
The upgrade program will extract all of the necessary packages. 
When prompted, type A to agree to the terms and conditions. 
 
117
4.

8.
9.
Specify the number that corresponds to the authentication method in the returned
list. If you select SSHkey, you must specify the SSHkey file path. If you select
root/password, you must specify the root password.
Specify the old version of the Cloud Pak for Data installation directory. The default
is /ibm/InstallPackage.
Specify the Cloud Pak for Data host file path. The default is
/ibm/InstallPackage/ibm-cp-app/cluster/hosts.
Specify the old version of the IBM Cloud Private installation directory when
upgrading IBM Cloud Private. The default is /ibm/InstallPackage/ibm-cp-app.
After the IBM Cloud Private upgrade completes, the information to access the
IBM Cloud Private console is displayed.The default URL is https://MASTER_1_IP
:8443, where MASTER_1_IP is the IP address of the master-1 node of your
cluster. 
If you created your cluster within a private network, use the public IP address of
the master-1 node to access the cluster. 
Troubleshooting tip: You can view the upgrade log file at installation_directory
/upgrade/InstallPackage/tmp/platform_upgrade.log. 
 
Clear the cache in your web browser.

5.
 Upgrading your Cloud Pak for Data installation 
You can run the IBM® Cloud Pak for Data installation to upgrade from Cloud Pak for
Data Version 1.2.1.1 or later to Version 2.1.0.2. If you are running version 1.2.0, you
must upgrade to version 1.2.1.1 before you can upgrade to version 2.1.0.2. 
 Before you begin 
 
Ensure that you completed the appropriate tasks for your environment:
 About this task 
 
 Procedure 
 
SSH into a node from which you can run kubectl and helm commands.For a
stand-alone installation of Cloud Pak for Data, SSH into the master node (
master-1) of your cluster as root.  
Ensure that you are authenticated to the following command-line interfaces:
Kubernetes command-line interface (kubectl). For example:kubectl get pods -n
kube-system 
Helm. For example:helm version --tls 
Or if TLS is not set up for Helm: 
helm version 
The command should return the version information for the Helm server and
Helm client. 
Docker registry. For example:docker login DOCKER_REGISTRY_URL -u USER_NAME -p 
 
Create the docker secret for an icp4d-anyuid service account:kubectl create
secret -n YOUR_NAMESPACE docker-registry icp4d-anyuid-docker-pull --docker-server=DOCKER_REGISTRY_URL --
docker-username=admin --docker-password=DOCKER_REGISTRY_PASSWORD 
Replace YOUR_NAMESPACE with the namespace where IBM Cloud Private is
deployed. The default namespace is zen. 
 
Change to the directory where you placed the upgrade installation files. By
default the files are in the /upgrade.
Stand-alone upgrade only: To upgrade GlusterFS to version 6.1, ensure that
the yum rpm sshpass is installed on the master-1 node (use the command
yum list installed | grep sshpass to check). Then run the following
command to automatically upgrade GlusterFS to version 6.1:./installer.x86_64.nnn --
platform-upgrade=gluster 
 
Environment Prerequisite tasks
Existing IBM Cloud Private
installations
Upgrade GlusterFS to version
6.1 (see Upgrading
GlusterFS)Obtaining the
installation files for upgrade
Stand-alone Cloud Pak for Data
installation
Obtaining the installation files for
upgradeUpgrading the
embedded version of IBM Cloud
Private

Run the following command to start the upgrade of IBM Cloud Private:./
installer.x86_64.nnn --upgrade 
 
Respond to the following prompts, and ensure the values match your original
installation:
Specify whether you want to use the default namespace (zen):
Enter Y to accept the default namespace.
Enter N to specify a different namespace. Follow the on-screen instructions
to set up a new namespace. 
 
Specify whether you want to use the default console port (31843):
Enter Y to accept the default console port.
Enter N to specify a different console port.
 
Specify the cluster Docker image prefix, for example
mycluster.icp:8500/zen, and press Enter.This is the address that your
nodes use to access the Docker registry. 
Specify whether the external Docker image prefix is the same as the cluster
Docker image prefix. For example, you might specify a different external
Docker image prefix if you are performing the installation from a host that is
external to your cluster. 
Enter Y to use the cluster Docker image prefix as the external Docker.
Enter N to specify a different external Docker image prefix. You are
prompted to enter the address of your Docker registry. The address can
have one of the following formats:
hostname
hostname:port_number
 
Specify whether you want to use the default storage class (oketi-gluster):
Enter Y to accept the default storage class.
Enter N to select a different storage class. If you don't have an appropriate
storage class, the installation program can use an NFS server for the
storage and create the required persistent volumes. However, you must
have an existing NFS server.Microsoft Azure only: Always enter N to select
the NFS entry. 
To select an existing storage class, specify the number that corresponds to
the storage class in the returned list. For example:
 
To use an NFS server, enter the number that corresponds to the NFS
entry in the returned list and specify the IP address and path (mount point)
of your NFS server. The installation program will use this NFS server for
storage and create the required persistent volumes on it.

4.

6.
Restriction: The No dynamic provisioning option is not recommended. 
 
Review the upgrade summary.
If the values are correct, enter Y to proceed with the upgrade.
If the values are incorrect, enter N to restart the prompts.
Wait for the upgrade to complete.The upgrade will not run against any modules
that have the same version. Only modules with an older version are upgraded. 
Tip: If an upgrade step fails, the installer exits. You can run the upgrade again by
running the following command:./installer_filename --upgrade 
 
Troubleshooting tip: If the upgrade stalls with the pod shop4info-type-
registry-0 being stuck in CrashLoopbackoff state, then complete the
following steps to resolve it:
Log in to the solr pod: kubectl -n YOUR_NAMESPACE -it solr-0 --
bash. Replace YOUR_NAMESPACE with the namespace where IBM Cloud
Private is deployed. The default namespace is zen.
Delete the shop4infoMain_shard* files in /opt/solr-7.4.0/server/solr/data.
Manually recreate the collection: solr create_collection -c
shop4infoMain -shards 2
-replicationFactor 1 -confname search -confdir search -p
8983;
 
 
If you have the Unified Governance and Integration add-on installed, restart its
related pods to ensure that discovery jobs can run successfully:kubectl
delete pod $(kubectl get pods -n zen | grep
'gov-app-config-service\|audit-trail-service\|gov-catalog-
search-service\|gov-social-service\|gov-user-prefs-
service\|data-masking-lite-service\|shop4info'
| awk '{print $1}') -n YOUR_NAMESPACE 
Replace YOUR_NAMESPACE with the namespace where IBM Cloud Private is
deployed. The default namespace is zen. 
 
 What to do next 
 
To verify that the upgrade succeeded, check the status of the pods to ensure they
are all running:kubectl get pods --all-namespaces 
If you upgraded from version 1.2.1.1, you might have pods such as zen-
metastoredb in ImagePullBackOff status that you need to delete. Complete
the following steps to delete a pod from default namespace zen: 
Describe the pod to retrieve the node it is present in:kubectl describe po zen-metastoredb-0
-n zen 
SSH into the node.
Sign into the docker registry:docker login DOCKER_REGISTRY_URL -u USER_NAME -p 
Pull the docker images:docker pull DOCKER_REGISTRY_URL/zen/zen-metastoredb:v2.1.0.1 
Exit the node.
Delete the pod:kubectl delete pod -n zen zen-metastoredb-0

7.
1.
2.
3.
Verify that the pod is now running:kubectl get pods -n zen | grep zen-metastoredb 
For GlusterFS only: To prevent data discovery jobs from failing or hanging, ensure
that the performance.write-behind: off parameter exists in your persistent volume
settings by completing the following steps:kubectl get pvc -n namespace |grep en-dedicated | awk
-F' ' '{print $3}' | xargs gluster volume info 
Replace namespace with your namespace, for example, zen. 
If performance.write-behind: off does not appear under Options
Reconfigured, complete the following steps to set it: 
Get the Volume
Name:kubectl get pvc -n namespace |grep en-dedicated | awk -F' ' '{print $3}' | xargs gluster volume
info 
Set performance.write-behind: off:gluster volume stop pvname 
gluster volume set performance.write-behind off
gluster volume start pvname 
gluster volume info pvname 
kubectl delete pod is-en-conductor-0 -n namespace 
Replace pvname with the Volume Name value from the previous step, and
replace namespace with your namespace from the previous step. 
Verify that the performance.write-behind parameter is now off:kubectl get pvc -n
namespace |grep en-dedicated | awk -F' ' '{print $3}' | xargs gluster volume info 
Replace namespace with your namespace, for example, zen. 
 
Troubleshooting tip: After the upgrade, if your projects all redirect to your getting
started page, you can fix this by deleting the /user-home/_global_/nginx-
conf.d/image-mgmt.conf file and entering /user-
home/.scripts/system/utils/nginx-reload to reload your nginx pods. 
 
122
-
-
 Uninstalling 
You can uninstall IBM® Cloud Pak for Data based on the type of installation you
have. 
 
Uninstalling the stand-alone version of Cloud Pak for Data 
 When you uninstall the stand-alone version of IBM Cloud Pak for Data, the
program is removed from your system along with IBM Cloud Private.
Uninstalling Cloud Pak for Data from an existing Red Hat OpenShift or IBM
Cloud Private environment 
 You can uninstall IBM Cloud Pak for Data from an existing OpenShift or IBM
Cloud Private environment.
123
 Uninstalling the stand-alone version of Cloud Pak
for Data 
When you uninstall the stand-alone version of IBM® Cloud Pak for Data, the
program is removed from your system along with IBM Cloud Private. 
 Procedure 
 
To uninstall the stand-alone version of Cloud Pak for Data, run the following script in
the InstallPackage directory:uninstall.sh 
The uninstaller restarts Docker. If you experience a hang on the system during this
step, run the following command on the master node (master-1) of your cluster:
systemctl --force reboot and then restart the uninstallation process. 
 
 
 
Parent topic:Uninstalling

6.
 Uninstalling Cloud Pak for Data from an existing
Red Hat OpenShift or IBM Cloud Private
environment 
You can uninstall IBM® Cloud Pak for Data from an existing OpenShift or IBM Cloud
Private environment. 
 About this task 
 
To uninstall Cloud Pak for Data from an existing OpenShift or IBM Cloud Private
environment, complete the following steps: 
 Procedure 
 
Get and save the list of PersistentVolumes that Cloud Pak for Data created.
IBM Cloud Private command:kubectl get pvc -n your-namespace --no-headers |awk '{print $3}' 
OpenShift command:oc get pvc -n your-namespace --no-headers |awk '{print $3}' 
Where your-namespace is the Cloud Pak for Data namespace. 
Remove all helm charts from the Cloud Pak for Data namespace using the
following script:#!/bin/bash
helm list --namespace your-namespace | awk '{ print $1 }' | tail -n +2 | while read line
do
       echo "running helm delete $line --purge"
       helm delete $line --purge
done 
Where your-namespace is the Cloud Pak for Data namespace.  
Delete the namespace.
IBM Cloud Private command:kubectl delete namespace your-namespace 
OpenShift command:oc delete your-namespace 
 Where your-namespace is the Cloud Pak for Data namespace. 
Delete each PersistentVolume in the list.
IBM Cloud Private command:kubectl delete pv pvname 
Where pvname is the name of each PersistentVolume.
OpenShift command:oc get pvc -n your-namespace --no-headers | awk '{print $3}' | while read
line
do
       echo "deleting pv $line"
       oc delete pv $line
done 
Where your-namespace is the Cloud Pak for Data namespace.
Clean up your storage accordingly.
Remove the Helm/Tiller instance.
 
Parent topic:Uninstalling 
 
125
